title: Python OOP - Final Exam
description: Comprehensive final exam covering all chapters: Clean Code, Classes/Objects, Encapsulation, Abstraction, Inheritance, and Polymorphism

questions.question: What does OOP stand for?
questions.explanation: OOP stands for Object-Oriented Programming - a paradigm based on objects.

questions.question: What are the four pillars of OOP?
questions.explanation: The four pillars are Encapsulation, Abstraction, Inheritance, and Polymorphism.

questions.question: What does DRY principle mean?
questions.explanation: DRY stands for Don't Repeat Yourself - avoid code duplication.

questions.question: What naming convention does PEP 8 recommend for variables?
questions.explanation: PEP 8 recommends snake_case for variables and functions.

questions.question: What keyword defines a class in Python?
questions.explanation: The 'class' keyword is used to define a class.

questions.question: What is __init__ method?
questions.explanation: __init__ is the constructor method that initializes new instances.

questions.question: What does 'self' represent?
questions.explanation: 'self' refers to the current instance of the class.

questions.question: What is encapsulation?
questions.explanation: Encapsulation bundles data and methods that operate on data.

questions.question: What does single underscore prefix indicate?
questions.explanation: Single underscore (_var) indicates protected/internal use by convention.

questions.question: What does double underscore trigger?
questions.explanation: Double underscore (__var) triggers name mangling to _ClassName__var.

questions.question: What decorator creates a property getter?
questions.explanation: @property decorator creates a getter method accessed like an attribute.

questions.question: What is abstraction?
questions.explanation: Abstraction hides complex implementation details, showing only essentials.

questions.question: What module provides ABC?
questions.explanation: The 'abc' module provides Abstract Base Classes support.

questions.question: What decorator marks abstract methods?
questions.explanation: @abstractmethod marks methods that subclasses must implement.

questions.question: Can you instantiate abstract classes?
questions.explanation: Cannot instantiate abstract classes with abstract methods - raises TypeError.

questions.question: What is inheritance?
questions.explanation: Inheritance allows a class to inherit attributes/methods from parent.

questions.question: What does super() do?
questions.explanation: super() returns proxy object allowing calls to parent class methods.

questions.question: What is method overriding?
questions.explanation: Method overriding is when child provides its own implementation of parent's method.

questions.question: What does MRO stand for?
questions.explanation: MRO stands for Method Resolution Order - determines method lookup order.

questions.question: What is polymorphism?

options.text: Many forms - same interface, different implementations

questions.explanation: Polymorphism means 'many forms' - same interface with different implementations.

questions.question: What is duck typing?

options.text: If it walks/quacks like duck, it's duck

questions.explanation: Duck typing: focus on object's behavior, not explicit type.

questions.question: What does __add__ define?
questions.explanation: __add__ defines behavior of the + operator.

questions.question: What does 'S' in SOLID mean?
questions.explanation: S = Single Responsibility Principle - class has one reason to change.

questions.question: What does 'O' in SOLID mean?
questions.explanation: O = Open/Closed Principle - open for extension, closed for modification.

questions.question: What does __str__ return?
questions.explanation: __str__ returns user-friendly string representation of object.

questions.question: What is a class variable?
questions.explanation: Class variables are shared across all instances of the class.

questions.question: What is composition?

options.text: Class contains instances of other classes

questions.explanation: Composition is 'has-a' relationship - class contains instances of others.

questions.question: What is a mixin?

options.text: Class providing methods via multiple inheritance

questions.explanation: Mixin provides specific functionality to other classes via multiple inheritance.

questions.question: What does KISS principle mean?
questions.explanation: KISS stands for Keep It Simple, Stupid - favor simplicity.

questions.question: What does YAGNI stand for?
questions.explanation: YAGNI = You Aren't Gonna Need It - don't add until needed.

questions.question: What is the Strategy pattern?
questions.explanation: Strategy pattern defines family of algorithms and makes them interchangeable.

questions.question: What is the Factory pattern?

options.text: Creating objects without specifying exact class

questions.explanation: Factory pattern creates objects without specifying exact class.

questions.question: What does isinstance() check?

options.text: If object is instance of class

questions.explanation: isinstance(obj, Class) checks if obj is instance of Class.

questions.question: What does issubclass() check?

options.text: If class is subclass of another

questions.explanation: issubclass(Child, Parent) checks if Child is subclass of Parent.

questions.question: What does __eq__ define?
questions.explanation: __eq__ defines how the == operator works.

questions.question: What does __lt__ define?
questions.explanation: __lt__ defines less than < comparison.

questions.question: What does __getitem__ enable?
questions.explanation: __getitem__ enables indexing obj[key].

questions.question: What does __iter__ enable?
questions.explanation: __iter__ makes object iterable in for loops.

questions.question: What is a concrete class?
questions.explanation: Concrete class implements all methods and can be instantiated.

questions.question: What does 'L' in SOLID mean?
questions.explanation: L = Liskov Substitution - subtypes must be substitutable for base types.

questions.question: PEP 8 is mandatory for all Python code.
questions.explanation: PEP 8 is a style guide, not mandatory, but consistency is important.

questions.question: Classes should have multiple responsibilities.
questions.explanation: Single Responsibility Principle: class should have one reason to change.

questions.question: Instance variables are unique to each instance.
questions.explanation: Instance variables are specific to each object instance.

questions.question: Class variables are shared by all instances.
questions.explanation: Class variables belong to the class and are shared.

questions.question: Python has true private attributes like Java.
questions.explanation: Python uses conventions and name mangling, but attributes remain accessible.

questions.question: Double underscore triggers name mangling.
questions.explanation: Double underscore (__var) causes Python to mangle name to _ClassName__var.

questions.question: Properties allow attribute-like access to methods.
questions.explanation: @property makes methods accessible like attributes.

questions.question: Abstract classes can be instantiated.
questions.explanation: Abstract classes with abstract methods cannot be instantiated.

questions.question: Subclasses must implement all abstract methods.
questions.explanation: Concrete subclasses must implement all abstract methods.

questions.question: Python supports multiple inheritance.
questions.explanation: Python allows a class to inherit from multiple parents.

questions.question: Method overriding changes parent's original method.
questions.explanation: Overriding provides new implementation in child; parent unchanged.

questions.question: Composition is more flexible than inheritance.
questions.explanation: Composition provides more flexibility and looser coupling.

questions.question: Duck typing requires explicit type declarations.
questions.explanation: Duck typing focuses on behavior, not explicit type declarations.

questions.question: Operator overloading uses magic methods.
questions.explanation: Operator overloading implemented using magic methods like __add__.

questions.question: SOLID principles improve code maintainability.
questions.explanation: SOLID principles lead to more maintainable and robust code.

questions.question: Polymorphism allows same interface with different implementations.
questions.explanation: Polymorphism enables same interface with different underlying implementations.

questions.question: Encapsulation improves code maintainability.
questions.explanation: Encapsulation protects internal state and improves maintainability.

questions.question: Abstraction hides unnecessary complexity.
questions.explanation: Abstraction hides complex implementation details.

questions.question: super() is required in child's __init__.
questions.explanation: super() is not required but recommended to initialize parent.

questions.question: Child class can add new methods not in parent.
questions.explanation: Child classes can add new methods beyond inherited ones.

questions.question: Which are OOP pillars? (Select all)
questions.explanation: Encapsulation, Abstraction, Inheritance are pillars. Compilation is not.

questions.question: Clean code principles? (Select all)
questions.explanation: DRY, KISS, YAGNI are principles. WET is anti-pattern.

questions.question: PEP 8 naming conventions? (Select all)
questions.explanation: Functions also use snake_case, not camelCase.

questions.question: Magic methods? (Select all)
questions.explanation: Magic methods have double underscores (dunder).

questions.question: Access level conventions? (Select all)
questions.explanation: Python uses no prefix (public), _ (protected), __ (mangled). ___ isn't standard.

questions.question: Property decorators? (Select all)
questions.explanation: @property is getter; @name.setter and @name.deleter follow. No @name.getter.

questions.question: Valid ABC imports? (Select all)
questions.explanation: All forms from 'abc' module valid. 'abstract' module doesn't exist.

questions.question: Inheritance types? (Select all)
questions.explanation: Python supports single, multiple, multilevel. Circular is invalid.

questions.question: Benefits of inheritance? (Select all)
questions.explanation: Inheritance provides reuse, hierarchy, extensibility - not speed.

questions.question: SOLID principles? (Select all)
questions.explanation: DRY is not part of SOLID acronym.

questions.question: Operator overload magic methods? (Select all)
questions.explanation: __add__, __sub__, __mul__ are operators. __delete__ doesn't exist.

questions.question: Comparison magic methods? (Select all)
questions.explanation: __eq__, __lt__, __gt__ are comparisons. __compare__ doesn't exist.

questions.question: Design patterns? (Select all)
questions.explanation: Strategy, Factory, Observer are patterns. Destructor is not.

questions.question: Benefits of polymorphism? (Select all)
questions.explanation: Polymorphism provides flexibility, reuse, extensibility - not auto-optimization.

questions.question: When to use composition? (Select all)
questions.explanation: Use composition for has-a, flexibility, loose coupling - not always.

questions.question: Complete: Define class
questions.explanation: Use 'class' keyword to define classes.

questions.question: Complete: Constructor
questions.explanation: __init__ is the constructor method.

questions.question: Complete: Property getter
questions.explanation: @property creates a getter method.

questions.question: Complete: Abstract class
questions.explanation: Inherit from ABC to create abstract class.

questions.question: Complete: Inherit from parent
questions.explanation: Use parentheses to inherit: class Child(Parent):

questions.question: Complete: Call parent __init__
questions.explanation: Use super().__init__() to call parent constructor.

questions.question: Complete: Addition operator
questions.explanation: Use __add__ to define + operator.

questions.question: Complete: String representation
questions.explanation: __str__ provides string representation.

questions.question: Complete: Abstract method
questions.explanation: Use @abstractmethod to mark abstract methods.

questions.question: Complete: Make iterable
questions.explanation: Use __iter__ to make object iterable.

questions.question: Create Simple Class with Methods
questions.description: Create Person class with __init__(name, age) and greet() method that returns 'Hello, I am {name}'.

questions.question: Implement Encapsulation with Properties
questions.description: Create BankAccount with private __balance. Add property getter and setter that validates balance >= 0.

questions.question: Create Abstract Base Class
questions.description: Create abstract Animal with abstract speak() method. Implement Dog class that returns 'Woof!'.
questions.starterCode:
from abc import ABC, abstractmethod

# Create Animal and Dog

questions.question: Inheritance with super()
questions.description: Create Vehicle with __init__(brand). Create Car(Vehicle) that adds model, calling super().__init__(brand).

questions.question: Operator Overloading
questions.description: Create Vector class with __add__ for vector addition and __mul__ for scalar multiplication.

questions.question: Polymorphism with Duck Typing
questions.description: Create make_sound(animal) function that calls animal.speak() - works with any object having speak().
questions.starterCode: # Create make_sound function and test classes

testCases.description: Works with any object having speak

questions.question: Multiple Inheritance
questions.description: Create Flyable with fly() and Swimmable with swim(). Create Duck inheriting both.

questions.question: Composition Pattern
questions.description: Create Engine class. Create Car that contains Engine instance (has-a relationship).
questions.starterCode: # Create Engine and Car with composition

questions.question: Strategy Pattern
questions.description: Implement Strategy pattern with different sorting strategies (ascending/descending).

questions.question: Factory Pattern
questions.description: Create ShapeFactory that creates Circle or Square based on shape_type parameter.

parts.question: What is a class?
parts.explanation: Class is a blueprint/template for creating objects.

parts.question: Object is instance of class
parts.explanation: Objects are concrete instances created from class.

parts.question: Access levels? (Select all)
parts.explanation: Python uses no prefix, _, and __ conventions.

parts.question: Properties allow controlled access
parts.explanation: Properties provide controlled access with validation.

parts.question: super() calls parent methods
parts.explanation: super() provides access to parent methods.

parts.question: Abstract classes cannot be instantiated
parts.explanation: Abstract classes with abstract methods cannot be instantiated.

parts.question: SOLID includes? (Select all)
parts.explanation: DRY is not part of SOLID acronym.

parts.question: Strategy pattern makes algorithms interchangeable
parts.explanation: Strategy pattern enables algorithm selection at runtime.

parts.question: What is Factory pattern?
parts.explanation: Factory creates objects without specifying exact class.
